skill.name: technical-decision-record
skill.description: Use when making technical decisions, choosing technologies, or documenting architectural choices. Creates ADRs (Architecture Decision Records).
skill.summary: Creates Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) to document technical choices with context, options, and consequences.
skill.author: ChaiWithJai

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing ADR templates and guidance for documenting technical decisions. No code execution, network calls, or cryptographic operations exist. All static findings are false positives: the scanner incorrectly flagged JSON metadata URLs as network risks, markdown code fences as shell execution, and documentation text about architectural decisions as cryptographic patterns. Safe for publication.

content.value_statement: Technical teams often lose context when decisions are made informally. This skill creates structured Architecture Decision Records that capture the problem, constraints, options considered, and consequences for future reference.
actual_capabilities: Guides users through a structured ADR creation process with 5 steps
Provides a markdown template with standard ADR sections
Helps identify constraints including technical, business, and compliance factors
Documents options with pros, cons, and estimated costs
Records consequences including positive, negative, risks, and reversibility
Identifies common mistakes in technical decision-making
limitations: Does not evaluate technical options or provide recommendations
Does not integrate with project management tools
Does not track ADR status or link related decisions automatically
Does not generate diagrams or visualizations

use_cases.title: New Technology Selection
use_cases.description: Document the evaluation process when choosing between React, Vue, or Angular for a new frontend project, capturing all constraints and trade-offs.
use_cases.target_user: Technical leads and architects evaluating new technologies

use_cases.title: Architecture Migration Planning
use_cases.description: Record the decision to migrate from a monolith to microservices, including the rationale, risks, and rollback plan.

use_cases.title: Process Change Documentation
use_cases.description: Formally document a new code review process or testing strategy with clear context and expected outcomes.

prompt_templates.title: Basic ADR Request
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to create an ADR for [DECISION TOPIC]. Help me document this technical decision with the problem, constraints, options, and consequences.

prompt_templates.title: Technology Evaluation
prompt_templates.prompt: We're deciding between [OPTION A], [OPTION B], and [OPTION C] for [USE CASE]. Create an ADR that captures our constraints, evaluates each option with pros and cons, and documents the final decision with reasoning.

prompt_templates.title: Architecture Change Request
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to document our decision to [ARCHITECTURAL CHANGE]. Include the trigger for this change, the risks involved, and a reversibility assessment. Use the full ADR template.

prompt_templates.title: Superseding Previous ADR
prompt_templates.prompt: ADR-[NUMBER] needs to be superseded because [REASON]. Create a new ADR that references the original, explains what changed, and provides updated context and recommendations.
prompt_templates.scenario: Updating a previous decision with new information

output_examples.input: Create an ADR for choosing PostgreSQL over MongoDB for our user profile service
output: # ADR-001: Use PostgreSQL for User Profile Service
We need to select a database for storing user profile data in our new microservice. The service will handle user accounts, preferences, and authentication tokens.
- Must integrate with existing Node.js backend
- Need ACID compliance for transaction safety
- Team has PostgreSQL experience, limited MongoDB experience
- Budget does not support managed database services
- Pros: ACID compliance, strong relationships, team familiarity
- Cons: Requires schema migration, less flexible for unstructured data
- Pros: Schema flexibility, easy horizontal scaling
- Cons: No ACID transactions, learning curve for team
- Positive: Reliable transactions, clear data model

output_examples.input: Document our decision to adopt gRPC for internal service communication
output: # ADR-042: Adopt gRPC for Internal Service Communication
Our microservices currently use REST over HTTP for inter-service communication. Performance bottlenecks and payload size are becoming issues as we scale.
- Must support TypeScript and Go services
- Need backward compatibility with existing REST APIs during transition
- Network efficiency is critical for high-volume services
We will adopt gRPC for new internal services with protobuf contracts.
- Positive: Smaller payloads, faster serialization, type safety
- Negative: Requires learning curve, browser clients cannot use gRPC directly
- Reversibility: Difficult - contracts become tightly coupled

best_practices: Always list at least 2 options, even if one is 'do nothing', to ensure decisions are justified
Match deliberation time to reversibility - spend more effort on irreversible decisions
Include all stakeholders in the Deciders field and get explicit sign-off before finalizing
anti_patterns: Making decisions without exploring alternatives - you cannot justify a choice without knowing what you chose against
Editing old ADRs when context changes - this loses the historical record; instead create a new ADR that supersedes the old one
Making decisions that affect teams without involving them - this creates surprise, resistance, and rework

faq.question: What is an ADR?
faq.answer: An ADR (Architecture Decision Record) is a document that captures important technical decisions, the context behind them, and the reasoning for the chosen approach. It serves as a reference for future team members.

faq.question: When should I create an ADR?
faq.answer: Create an ADR when making technology choices, architectural changes, selecting third-party services, changing established patterns, or any decision you want to reference later.

faq.question: How detailed should an ADR be?
faq.answer: Match detail to reversibility. Low-stakes reversible decisions need less detail. High-stakes irreversible decisions should capture full context, options, risks, and consequences.

faq.question: Can I edit an existing ADR?
faq.answer: No. ADRs are immutable historical records. If circumstances change, create a new ADR that supersedes the old one with a reference to the original.

faq.question: What belongs in the Consequences section?
faq.answer: Document positive benefits, negative costs, identified risks with mitigations, and reversibility assessment (Easy, Moderate, Difficult, or Irreversible).

faq.question: How do I number my ADRs?
faq.answer: Use sequential numbering like ADR-001, ADR-002. Include the number in the filename and title for easy reference and linking between related decisions.
